CONCLUSION: Violation of Article 5 - Right to liberty and security (Article 5-3 - Length of pre-trial detention)
JUDGES: David Thór Björgvinsson;George Nicolaou;Ineta Ziemele;Krzysztof Wojtyczek;Päivi Hirvelä;Vincent A. De Gaetano;Zdravka Kalaydjieva
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and , having been sentenced by the NORP courts and subsequently transferred to GPE , is currently serving a prison sentence in GPE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was arrested on suspicion of murder .

CARDINAL . On DATE a judge authorised the applicant ’s remand in custody , citing the following reasons : the applicant might abscond and impede the investigation ; and in view of the severity of the offence , his prior convictions and his absence of a registered place of residence .

CARDINAL . On DATE another judge authorised the applicant ’s detention for DATE , citing the following reasons : the gravity of the offence , the circumstances surrounding it and the applicant ’s character . The judge saw no reason to change the preventive measure imposed on the applicant .

CARDINAL . On DATE the same judge authorised the applicant ’s detention for a further DATE ( until DATE ) , citing the following reasons : the applicant ’s character and the need to carry out a forensic psychiatric examination . The judge saw no reason to change the preventive measure imposed on the applicant . The applicant complained about this decision to a prosecutor and pointed out that he had a wife and minor children who were dependent on him .

CARDINAL . On DATE the prosecutor examined his complaint and rejected it on the grounds that the applicant was charged with a serious crime . His character ( the applicant ’s CARDINAL prior convictions were noted ) and his family responsibilities had not dissuaded him from committing a serious crime . The applicant lodged another complaint challenging his preventive measure ; the same prosecutor rejected it on DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE another judge authorised the applicant ’s detention for DATE , citing the following reasons : the applicant ’s character
CARDINAL . On DATE the final indictment was issued against the applicant .
CARDINAL . On DATE the case file was sent for trial to ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was committed for trial and the first hearing was scheduled for DATE . The preventive measure imposed on the applicant ( remand in custody ) remained unchanged ; no reasons were given .
CARDINAL . No more detention orders were issued in respect of the applicant .
CARDINAL . DATE the trial hearings before ORG took place , and the trial was concluded on the latter date .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG pronounced the judgment . It convicted the applicant of aggravated murder and hooliganism ; he was sentenced to CARDINAL years’ imprisonment . As an additional penalty the court ordered his expulsion from GPE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the appellate court upheld the ruling of the first­instance court .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant ’s appeal on points of law was dismissed .
CARDINAL . On an unspecified date the applicant was transferred to a prison in NORP to serve his sentence , where he was detained until DATE .

CARDINAL . On several occasions the prison authorities refused long - term visits in prison by the applicant ’s partner , PERSON , and her daughter , PERSON , born in DATE , who he considered to be his only family in GPE . The applicant lodged complaints against these refusals .

CARDINAL . On DATE the administration of Daugavpils Prison referred to section CARDINAL of LAW and observed that the applicant had a right to receive a long - term visit by PERSON if he was noted as her father on her birth certificate . The applicant could not receive a long­term visit from PERSON because she was not considered to be a close family member . It appears that the applicant further complained to ORG vietu pārvalde ) and the NORP prison administration informed that authority that the applicant had not received any short - term visits from PERSON during his imprisonment .
CARDINAL . According to the Government , on DATE the applicant requested a long - term visit by his partner and her daughter . They did not have more information concerning this request .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant requested a long - term visit by his partner and her daughter . In reply , he received the following statement written on his request : “ You have received an answer in writing in this respect ” .
CARDINAL . According to the applicant , he received a short - term visit from PERSON and PERSON in NORP prison in DATE .

CARDINAL . The applicant was refused a short - term visit during his admission to ORG in GPE . He complained about the refusal and on DATE he received a reply that only tuberculosis patients were allowed to receive short - term visits with the permission of a doctor , or seriously ill patients with the permission of the head of the hospital .

CARDINAL . According to the Government , on CARDINAL DATE the applicant requested another long - term visit by his partner and her daughter . On DATE this request was refused , given that PERSON was not a “ close family member ” of his within the meaning of section CARDINAL of LAW . The applicant was informed that he could be visited by PERSON if he was recorded as her father on her birth certificate .
CARDINAL . Subsequently , a complaint by the applicant concerning long - term visits was accepted for review by the ORG ’s office .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG delivered his opinion , which was not binding on the domestic authorities . He noted that the application of section CARDINAL of LAW was not uniform among the domestic authorities , but that in FAC , in particular , long - term visits were often refused in the form of a simple reply using vague phrases such as “ to be refused in accordance with the law ” or “ impossible to determine the visit ’s usefulness ” . The refusal in the applicant ’s case had been given in CARDINAL sentence , informing him that PERSON was not considered to be a close family member of his . No other options had been considered , such as , for example , whether the applicant could receive a long - term visit by PERSON in another capacity ( and not only on the basis of their relationship centred on PERSON ) . No individual assessment had been made in his case , which had breached the rules of administrative procedure .

CARDINAL . On the one hand , the ORG observed that even if the applicant had complained to ORG and the administrative courts about the refusal of long - term visits , it was most likely that he would not have been granted such visits ; rather , he could only have received compensation . On the other hand , the ORG informed the applicant that he could lodge a complaint with ORG ( PERSON tiesa ) about the compliance of the legal provision concerning such long­term visits with LAW ( PERSON ) .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant lodged a complaint with ORG . By a decision of DATE it was dismissed on formal grounds for non - compliance with the applicable admissibility criteria .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant forwarded a complaint to ORG , which it received on DATE , about the refusals by the administration of FAC to allow long - term visits by his partner and her daughter . He claimed that had been told orally that visits by them would not be allowed , and he considered this blanket refusal to be in violation of LAW . He pointed out that he had not received any long - term visits since his conviction .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG examined and dismissed the applicant ’s complaint .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant applied to the administrative courts with his complaint concerning long - term visits .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG exempted the applicant from the payment of court fees and admitted the complaint for examination in part , in so far as it concerned an action of a public authority ( faktiskā rīcība ) ( namely the refusal to allow long - term visits by PERSON and PERSON ) . The applicant ’s compensation claim for CARDINAL NORP lati ( ORG ) was not admitted , as he had not lodged such a claim with ORG ( in contrast to his complaint concerning an action of a public authority ) . The applicant lodged an ancillary complaint against this decision with ORG , which was rejected on CARDINAL DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG examined and dismissed the applicant ’s complaint . The applicant was present during the hearing and submitted that his relationship with PERSON and PERSON had broken down owing to the refusal by the prison authorities to allow long - term visits . The district court found that the applicant had on numerous occasions asked for permission to receive long - term visits by PERSON and PERSON It considered that the authorities’ refusals to allow such visits had constituted an interference with the applicant ’s rights under LAW and as also established by LAW . Notwithstanding that , the district court held as follows :

“ The court notes that the applicant could prove his father - daughter relationship by showing the birth certificate of PERSON , where he is recorded as her father . The defendant [ ORG ] confirmed during the hearing that the applicant could receive a long - term visit by his daughter , if he produced her birth certificate . The applicant , for his part , considered that he did not need to prove anything .

The court finds that the prison administration has not set an insurmountable obstacle by asking the applicant to provide documents attesting to his family relationships . The case file shows that the applicant has received several short - term visits by his partner , PERSON , and her daughter , PERSON , during which they could [ in principle ] have complied with the formal requirement to show PERSON ’s birth certificate in order to receive a long­term visit [ by her ] .

In view of the above , the court concludes that the applicant and the people from whom he has asked to receive a long - term visit have not taken minimal steps to prove the applicant ’s relationship with PERSON This created doubts that the applicant had a family relationship with PERSON Thus the defendant ’s refusal to allow long - term visits by PERSON and PERSON was justified . ”

CARDINAL . The applicant lodged an appeal against this ruling , which was refused on several occasions on formal grounds ( failure to pay court fees and failure to provide a translation of the statement of appeal in NORP ) . After several unsuccessful ancillary complaints about these procedural decisions , on DATE ORG examined his appeal against the first - instance court ’s refusal to exempt him from the payment of court fees . The case was sent back to the first - instance court to decide on the exemption .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG partially exempted the applicant from the payment of court fees for an appeal and set a time - limit for payment of the reduced court fees in the amount of ORG . This decision was sent to the applicant ’s address in prison in GPE , as he had not informed the district court that he had been transferred to a prison in GPE ( see below ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG found that the applicant had not paid the reduced court fees for lodging an appeal and had also not informed it of his transfer to another prison . As the applicant had failed to rectify the procedural shortcomings in his appeal ( he had not paid the reduced court fees ) , his appeal against the CARDINAL DATE ruling was therefore considered as not submitted . This decision took effect on DATE , as the applicant did not lodge an ancillary complaint against it on time .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant asked to be transferred to GPE to continue serving his sentence there .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was informed that a request had been sent to the NORP authorities in accordance with applicable law .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was informed that the NORP authorities had accepted the request and that he would be transferred to GPE to continue serving his sentence .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was transferred to a prison in GPE , in view of his scheduled transfer to GPE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was handed over to the NORP authorities at FAC .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant informed the ORG that he intended to pursue his application in GPE .

“ The administration of a prison may also authorise long - term visits by another individual , provided that prior to his or her imprisonment the convicted person had a common household or a child with that individual . ”

CARDINAL . The Law of Administrative Procedure ( ORG procesa likums ) took effect on DATE . It provides for the right to challenge administrative acts ( administratīvais akts ) and actions of a public authority ( faktiskā rīcība ) before the administrative courts .
